articles.headline: A Meter So Expensive, It Creates Parking Spots
articles.snippet: A program using new technology and flexible pricing based on supply and demand appears to have made finding a parking space easier in parts of San Francisco.
articles.abstract: A program using new technology and flexible pricing based on supply and demand appears to have made finding a parking space easier in parts of San Francisco.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The maddening quest for street parking is not just a tribulation for drivers, but a trial for cities. As much as a third of the traffic in some areas has been attributed to drivers circling as they hunt for spaces. The wearying tradition takes a toll in lost time, polluted air and, when drivers despair, double-parked cars that clog traffic even more.
articles.byline: By Michael Cooper and Jo Craven McGinty

articles.headline: Bad Loans at State-Run Banks Add to India’s Woes
articles.snippet: India, whose once red-hot economy has started to cool, is trying to cope with debt and deficit problems that will put strains on the annual budget to be presented to Parliament on Friday.
articles.abstract: India, whose once red-hot economy has started to cool, is trying to cope with debt and deficit problems that will put strains on the annual budget to be presented to Parliament on Friday.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — When people talk about Europe’s “government debt problem” they mean something easy to describe: countries that borrowed more money than they can easily pay back. In India, it’s a bit more complicated.

articles.headline: Paving Path to Fraud on Wall St.
articles.snippet: Just days before Greg Smith publicly criticized Goldman Sachs, a bill removing safeguards for investors sailed through the House. It is now on the floor of the Senate.
articles.abstract: Just days before Greg Smith publicly criticized Goldman Sachs, a bill removing safeguards for investors sailed through the House. It is now on the floor of the Senate.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nearly 20 years ago, Bankers Trust was riding high. The bank, based in New York, had become known as an expert in then-newfangled derivative securities, and the profits were flowing in. In an era where commercial banks were often viewed as stodgy and unimaginative, it stood out as a shining light. Corporate treasurers sought its insights about ways to maximize income from idle cash. Wall Street firms scrambled to compete.

articles.headline: For Apple, Pressure Builds Over App Store Fraud
articles.snippet: Complaints about mysterious transactions on iTunes are undermining the store’s reputation as the safest of online shopping environments.
articles.abstract: Complaints about mysterious transactions on iTunes are undermining the store’s reputation as the safest of online shopping environments.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a little over an hour, Ryan Matthew Pierson racked up $437.71 in iTunes charges for virtual currency that he could use to buy guns, nightclubs and cars in iMobsters, a popular iPhone game. One problem: Mr. Pierson, a technology writer in Texas, has never played iMobsters.
articles.byline: By Evelyn M. Rusli and Brian X. Chen

articles.headline: Accused G.I. ‘Snapped’ Under Strain, Official Says
articles.snippet: The American staff sergeant suspected of killing 16 Afghan villagers had been drinking alcohol and suffering from stress tied to his fourth combat tour, a senior official said.
articles.abstract: The American staff sergeant suspected of killing 16 Afghan villagers had been drinking alcohol and suffering from stress tied to his fourth combat tour, a senior official said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The American staff sergeant suspected of killing 16 Afghan villagers had been drinking alcohol — a violation of military rules in combat zones — and suffering from the stress related to his fourth combat tour and tensions with his wife about the deployments on the night of the massacre, a senior American official said Thursday.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and William Yardley

articles.headline: Firm Romney Founded Is Tied to Chinese Surveillance
articles.snippet: As the Chinese government forges ahead on an effort to blanket the country with cameras, Bain Capital, the private equity firm founded by Mitt Romney, stands to profit.
articles.abstract: As the Chinese government forges ahead on an effort to blanket the country with cameras, Bain Capital, the private equity firm founded by Mitt Romney, stands to profit.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — As the Chinese government forges ahead on a multibillion-dollar effort to blanket the country with surveillance cameras, one American company stands to profit: Bain Capital, the private equity firm founded by Mitt Romney.
articles.byline: By Andrew Jacobs and Penn Bullock

articles.headline: G.O.P. Strategy for Hispanic Voters: It’s the Economy
articles.snippet: In swing states like Colorado, Republicans are using concerns about the sluggish recovery to appeal to Hispanic voters, long a solid part of the Democratic base.
articles.abstract: In swing states like Colorado, Republicans are using concerns about the sluggish recovery to appeal to Hispanic voters, long a solid part of the Democratic base.
articles.lead_paragraph: PUEBLO, Colo. — For many years, and multiple election cycles, Republicans talked about the growing Hispanic vote in America like moonstruck, misunderstood boys at a high school dance. They could not connect, despite believing that they shared much in common, especially with socially conservative, religious Hispanic voters who would one day realize how charming Republicans could be.

articles.headline: Karzai Lashes Out at NATO Over Deaths
articles.snippet: President Hamid Karzai said he was at “the end of the rope” over the deaths of Afghan civilians.
articles.abstract: President Hamid Karzai said he was at “the end of the rope” over the deaths of Afghan civilians.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The last thing President Obama did before going to bed Thursday night was to call President Hamid Karzai, whose day was just getting started here.
articles.byline: By Matthew Rosenberg and Helene Cooper

articles.headline: In Sit-Down Restaurants, an Economic Indicator
articles.snippet: Sales at restaurants with waiters — a reliable past guide to how the economy is going — jumped 8.7 percent last year.
articles.abstract: Sales at restaurants with waiters — a reliable past guide to how the economy is going — jumped 8.7 percent last year.
articles.lead_paragraph: Have you been eating more at restaurants with waiters rather than fast-food joints?
